work.p: The husband and wife together at night appears consistently as one of the images used in the poem ultimately titled "Song of Myself" throughout all of the editions of Leaves of Grass. See, for instance, the line: "The old husband sleeps by his wife and the young husband sleeps by his wife" (1855, p. 23).

Parts of this manuscript, especially the second line, might have contributed to the following passage in the preface and to the 1855 Leaves of Grass: "Does the young man think often of him? and the young woman think often of him? and do the middleaged and the old think of him?" (p. xi).

a machine readable transcription

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: This manuscript may have been written in the early 1850s, as Whitman was preparing material for the first (1855) edition of Leaves of Grass. The language and imagery in the manuscript are similar to language and imagery used in the preface to that edition and in the first poem, eventually titled "Song of Myself."

lg.l:
you young woman, thinking of man,
and thinking of the bashful,
longh longing, loving, thinking
alone at night,

You wife of
a your
husband,

You husband of
a your
wife,—you old
husband, and you middle‑aged or
young husband,
